At the risk of criticism for replying to my own post ...

If a version of =
JUnit 4 were made available for Java 1.4 - my 
personal preferrence might b=
e to have a base class extension style 
of API with call back methods simil=
ar to JUnit 3.  (Note: A more 
standard call back syntax ... i.e. use preTe=
st()/postTest() [or even 
preTestCB()/postTestCB()] to wrap setUp()/testDow=
n() could be 
favored.)

This provides a comfortable migration (learning) p=
ath for developers 
and, more importantly, provides a strategy to leverage =
all of the 
convenience extensions companies have built upon JUnit 3.

If o=
ne prefers JavaDoc annotations you can always use TestNG.  Why 
go down tha=
t path a second time?


_Marvin
